--- title: "7-Mean Tests" subtitle: " " author: "Felipe Melo" institute: "Nottingham Trent University - UK" from: markdown+emoji format: revealjs: theme: [default, custom.scss] incremental: false chalkboard: true logo: img/ntu_logo.png footer: "Research Methods & Data Analysis" slide-number: true transition: slide background-transition: fade #auto-stretch: true title-block-banner: true --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## You should know today: - Know when to use mean tests - Understand means and variances - Parametric nd non-parametric versions - T-tests, ANOVA, etc... - Paired tests ## Types of variables (review) ::::{.columns} :::{.column .fragment} **Categorical** ![](https://static-assets.codecademy.com/Courses/Hypothesis-Testing/Intro_to_variable_types_3.png) ::: :::{.column .fragment} **Numerical** ![](https://static-assets.codecademy.com/Courses/Hypothesis-Testing/Intro_to_variable_types_4.png) ::: :::: ## Back to the toolbox ![](img/toolkit.png){fig-align="center"} ## Basics ![](img/comparing-means.png){fig-align="center"} ## One-Sample ![](https://statstest.b-cdn.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Single-Sample-T-Test-1-1024x512.png) ## Assumptions - Continuous - Normally Distributed - Random Sample - Enough Data ![](https://statstest.b-cdn.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Screen-Shot-2020-02-06-at-5.23.39-PM.png){.absolute right=10 top=30 width=50%} ## Let's code it :::{.panel-tabset} ## Penguins ![](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/figures/lter_penguins.png){width="40%" fig-align="left"} ![](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/figures/culmen_depth.png){.absolute width="40%" right=10 bottom=80} ## Code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(586) x<-rnorm(50) t.test(x, mu = 0, alternative = "two.sided") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` One Sample t-test data: x t = -0.31154, df = 49, p-value = 0.7567 alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -0.2633214 0.1926358 sample estimates: mean of x -0.03534281 ``` ::: ::: ## Example ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% filter(species=="Adelie") %>% select(bill_length_mm)->x t.test(x, mu = 43.92, alternative = "two.sided") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` One Sample t-test data: x t = -23.662, df = 150, p-value < 2.2e-16 alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 43.92 95 percent confidence interval: 38.36312 39.21966 sample estimates: mean of x 38.79139 ``` ::: ::: ## Graph ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggdensity(x = "bill_length_mm", add = "mean", rug = TRUE, color = "#00AFBB", fill = "#00AFBB")+ geom_vline(xintercept = 38.79139) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ## One-sided differences :::{.panel-tabset} ## Context
Find more statistics at Statista ## Code ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Fetch the data from Our World in Data. RUN ONLY ONCE url <- "https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv" df <- read_csv(url) # Prepare the data df_latest <- df %>% group_by(location) %>% slice_tail(n = 1) %>% mutate(deaths_per_million = total_deaths / population * 1000000) df_latest %>% filter(location=="Brazil") %>% select(deaths_per_million) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 Ã— 2 # Groups: location [1] location deaths_per_million 1 Brazil 3261. ``` ::: ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(df_latest, aes(x = deaths_per_million)) + geom_histogram(fill = "steelblue") + labs(title = "COVID-19 Deaths per Million") + theme_minimal() + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+ geom_vline(xintercept=3261) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## t-test ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} t.test(df_latest$deaths_per_million, mu = 3261, alternative = "less") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` One Sample t-test data: df_latest$deaths_per_million t = -23.694, df = 233, p-value < 2.2e-16 alternative hypothesis: true mean is less than 3261 95 percent confidence interval: -Inf 1385.595 sample estimates: mean of x 1245.092 ``` ::: ::: ## Is it normal? ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} shapiro.test(df_latest$deaths_per_million) ## Non-normal!! ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Shapiro-Wilk normality test data: df_latest$deaths_per_million W = 0.8578, p-value = 6.709e-14 ``` ::: ::: ## Non-parametirc test ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} wilcox.test(df_latest$deaths_per_million, mu = 3261, alternative = "less") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Wilcoxon signed rank test with continuity correction data: df_latest$deaths_per_million V = 910, p-value < 2.2e-16 alternative hypothesis: true location is less than 3261 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Two independent groups :::{.panel-tabset} ## Data ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Data in two numeric vectors women_weight <- c(38.9, 61.2, 73.3, 21.8, 63.4, 64.6, 48.4, 48.8, 48.5) men_weight <- c(67.8, 60, 63.4, 76, 89.4, 73.3, 67.3, 61.3, 62.4) # Create a data frame my_data <- data.frame( group = rep(c("Woman", "Man"), each = 9), weight = c(women_weight, men_weight) ) my_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` group weight 1 Woman 38.9 2 Woman 61.2 3 Woman 73.3 4 Woman 21.8 5 Woman 63.4 6 Woman 64.6 7 Woman 48.4 8 Woman 48.8 9 Woman 48.5 10 Man 67.8 11 Man 60.0 12 Man 63.4 13 Man 76.0 14 Man 89.4 15 Man 73.3 16 Man 67.3 17 Man 61.3 18 Man 62.4 ``` ::: ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} library("ggpubr") ggboxplot(my_data, x = "group", y = "weight", color = "group", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"), ylab = "Weight", xlab = "Groups") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Check assumptions - Are the two samples independents? - Are the data from each of the 2 groups follow a normal distribution? - Do the two populations have the same variances? ::: ## Testing normal distribution ::: {.cell output-location='default'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Shapiro-Wilk normality test for Men's weights with(my_data, shapiro.test(weight[group == "Man"]))# p = 0.1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Shapiro-Wilk normality test data: weight[group == "Man"] W = 0.86425, p-value = 0.1066 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Shapiro-Wilk normality test for Women's weights with(my_data, shapiro.test(weight[group == "Woman"])) # p = 0.6 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Shapiro-Wilk normality test data: weight[group == "Woman"] W = 0.94266, p-value = 0.6101 ``` ::: ::: ## Testing equal variances ::: {.cell output-location='default'} ```{.r .cell-code} var.test(weight ~ group, data = my_data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` F test to compare two variances data: weight by group F = 0.36134, num df = 8, denom df = 8, p-value = 0.1714 alternative hypothesis: true ratio of variances is not equal to 1 95 percent confidence interval: 0.08150656 1.60191315 sample estimates: ratio of variances 0.3613398 ``` ::: ::: ## Unpaired two-samples t-test ::: {.cell output-location='default'} ```{.r .cell-code} t.test(women_weight, men_weight, var.equal = TRUE) # method 1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Two Sample t-test data: women_weight and men_weight t = -2.7842, df = 16, p-value = 0.01327 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -29.748019 -4.029759 sample estimates: mean of x mean of y 52.10000 68.98889 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} t.test(weight ~ group, data = my_data, var.equal = TRUE) # Method 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Two Sample t-test data: weight by group t = 2.7842, df = 16, p-value = 0.01327 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group Man and group Woman is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 4.029759 29.748019 sample estimates: mean in group Man mean in group Woman 68.98889 52.10000 ``` ::: ::: ## Non-parametric test ::: {.panel-tabset} ## Wilcoxon ![](https://datatab.net/assets/tutorial/Wilcoxon-Test.png) source: ## Data ::: {.cell output-location='default'} ```{.r .cell-code} my_data %>% mutate(subject = rep(1:9,2)) %>% pivot_wider(names_from = group, values_from = weight) %>% mutate(diff=Woman-Man) %>% arrange(diff) %>% mutate(signal=ifelse(diff>0, "pos", "neg")) %>% mutate(rank=9:1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 Ã— 6 subject Woman Man diff signal rank 1 4 21.8 76 -54.2 neg 9 2 1 38.9 67.8 -28.9 neg 8 3 5 63.4 89.4 -26 neg 7 4 7 48.4 67.3 -18.9 neg 6 5 9 48.5 62.4 -13.9 neg 5 6 8 48.8 61.3 -12.5 neg 4 7 6 64.6 73.3 -8.7 neg 3 8 2 61.2 60 1.20 pos 2 9 3 73.3 63.4 9.9 pos 1 ``` ::: ::: ## Calculaion ![](https://datatab.net/assets/tutorial/Calculate-Wilcoxon-test.png) ## Code ::: {.cell output-location='default'} ```{.r .cell-code} wilcox.test(weight ~ group, data = my_data, exact = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction data: weight by group W = 66, p-value = 0.02712 alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## More than two independent groups :::{.panel-tabset} ## Context ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## ANOVA ::: {.cell output-location='default'} ```{.r .cell-code} anova(lm(bill_length_mm~species, data=penguins)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Variance Table Response: bill_length_mm Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) species 2 7194.3 3597.2 410.6 < 2.2e-16 *** Residuals 339 2969.9 8.8 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ::: ## Sum of Squares $$SS=\sum_{i=0}^{n} (X_i - \bar{X})^2$$ See [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PEMXgayXBg) to understand the logic of an ANOVA ## Visualising ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ## Anova Table ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |Source of Variation | Sum of Squares (SS)| Degrees of Freedom (df)| Mean Square (MS)| F-value| p-value| |:---------------------|-------------------:|-----------------------:|----------------:|-------:|-------:| |Between Groups | 100| 2| 50.00| 4.5| 0.05| |Within Groups (Error) | 200| 15| 13.33| NA| NA| |Total | 300| 17| NA| NA| NA| ::: ::: ## Kruskal-Wallis (non-parametric) ::: {.cell output-location='default'} ```{.r .cell-code} kruskal.test(bill_length_mm~species, data=penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test data: bill_length_mm by species Kruskal-Wallis chi-squared = 244.14, df = 2, p-value < 2.2e-16 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Paired designs ![](img/paired.png){fig-align=center} ## Paired graphs :::{.panel-tabset} ## Pairs in space ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Weight of the mice before treatment blockA <-c(200.1, 190.9, 192.7, 213, 241.4, 196.9, 172.2, 185.5, 205.2, 193.7) # Weight of the mice after treatment blockB <-c(392.9, 393.2, 345.1, 393, 434, 427.9, 422, 383.9, 392.3, 352.2) # Create a data frame my_data2 <- data.frame( group = rep(c("blockA", "blockB"), each = 10), weight = c(blockA, blockB) ) my_data2 %>% mutate(subject=rep(1:10,2)) %>% ggplot(aes(group,weight))+ geom_boxplot(aes(fill=group), alpha=0.5)+ geom_line(aes(group=subject))+ geom_point(size=2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Pairs in time ![](img/phylo.png){fig-align="center" width="60%"} source: [Santos et al 2015](https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0113109) ::: ## More than two independent samples :::{.panel-tabset} ## 2-way ANOVA graph ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} ToothGrowth$dose<-as.factor(ToothGrowth$dose) ToothGrowth %>% ggboxplot(x = "dose", y = "len", color = "supp", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](07_mean_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## 2-way ANOVA Code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} anova(lm(len~dose+supp, data = ToothGrowth)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Variance Table Response: len Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) dose 2 2426.43 1213.22 82.811 < 2.2e-16 *** supp 1 205.35 205.35 14.017 0.0004293 *** Residuals 56 820.43 14.65 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ::: ## 2-way ANOVA with interaction ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # These two calls are equivalent res.aov3 <- aov(len ~ supp * dose, data = ToothGrowth) res.aov3 <- aov(len ~ supp + dose + supp:dose, data = ToothGrowth) summary(res.aov3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) supp 1 205.4 205.4 15.572 0.000231 *** dose 2 2426.4 1213.2 92.000 < 2e-16 *** supp:dose 2 108.3 54.2 4.107 0.021860 * Residuals 54 712.1 13.2 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Post-hoc comparisons ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} TukeyHSD(res.aov3, which = "dose") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Tukey multiple comparisons of means 95% family-wise confidence level Fit: aov(formula = len ~ supp + dose + supp:dose, data = ToothGrowth) $dose diff lwr upr p adj 1-0.5 9.130 6.362488 11.897512 0.0e+00 2-0.5 15.495 12.727488 18.262512 0.0e+00 2-1 6.365 3.597488 9.132512 2.7e-06 ``` ::: ::: ## End of DA class{.center}

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
